arch:property.oc:show_val: Locus 40 is the north wall of the stairway in the hypocaust room. The wall rests on top of the floor of the hypocaust room (Locus 42), and abuts the West Precinct Wall (Locus 38). The stairs are incorporated directly into Locus 40, and were clearly constructed at the same time. The material used in the wall is quite varied  hewn and dressed sandstone ashlars widely ranging in size (from cobbles to boulders), as well as two reused column drums (with a diameter of 0.40 m) were used, and snecking stones are employed throughout, even with a piece of marble tile being used as snecking. As this wall supports a stairway, the number of rows clearly decreases from east to west, so at its height there are 6 course extant while at the west there is only one course. The wall is one to two rows thick. This wall is assigned to the stage of reconfiguration (Stage 4) along with the stairway because of the prevalence of reused materials, and the fact that it not only abuts the West Precinct Wall (and the stairway abuts Locus 25), but the floor of the hypocaust room continues underneath the wall. The reusing of ashlars, column drums, and marble tiles and the roughness of construction is not seen in the main features of the bath complex, and so these points taken collectively lead us to believe that this was a later addition to and reworking of the bath complex. The column drums help, along with the hexagonal pavers of Locus 102, to suggest a date for this reconfiguration stage as post-363  it is likely that these reused pieces were collapse from the earthquake of 363 and so available for easy reuse. The blocking of some of the doorways of the complex (Loci 56 and 59) and the construction of this stairway suggests a reorientation in the traffic flow through the complex with this reconfiguration. Further excavation to the west will hopefully clarify the plan of the entire complex and also any other alterations to that plan through time. See the description of Locus 72 for further discussion of the implications of this stairway.

Phase X: Site abandonment after major collapse dating to the Byzantine period from the CE 4th to 5th c. New drainage systems are installed including that associated with the newly built west precinct wall.
North wall of the stairway in the hypocaust room (Locus 72)
0.50 m north south -by- 4.40 m east west.
